attributes.alt: Cover for This Shoe Needs a Foot by Caedyn Melach. Cover shows 8 different animal paws, a ruler, and a single shoe with a scared face in the center.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to play a game, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
Which animals are trying to help the shoe?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of math words.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like small, big, short, tall and long.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Show children pictures of people wearing shoes and have them say if the shoes are worn by an adult or a child.
Challenge children to sort shoes by size.
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
What big and little animals can you find in this book?
Let’s pretend you are trying to put on a shoe that is too small.
In the book, the animals use a ruler to measure the foot. What else could we measure with a ruler?
In the book, the shoe shows lots of feelings. Draw one of them. How can you show sad feelings? How can you show happy feelings?
Draw a picture of you wearing your favorite shoes.
What other words do you know that start with the /sh/ sound?
Can you use blocks to create a big shoe?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share inferences, predictions, or conclusions about a text.
Understand and use growing number of math words.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like small, big, short, tall and long.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination.
Show children a series of pictures and ask them if what they see is the same or different.
Have children ask their own questions about each image.
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
Find something in a book that is big or small.
Set up a pretend shoe store and help customers looking for shoes.
Can you find three things in the room that are very small?
Draw two animals: one big and one small. I will label the pictures for you when you’re done.
Draw or make a big box and a little box.
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word
? Can you think of other words that start with that letter?
Build a tall tower out of blocks. Then build a smaller one next to it.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill
, engage children in a movement activity, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share inferences, predictions, or conclusions about a text.
Understand and use a growing number of math words.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like small, big, short, tall and long.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Review with children a series of pictures and sort them by “long” or “short.”
Discuss with children what’s alike or different about the pictures.
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
How did measuring the foot help solve the problem in the story?
Show how you would walk if your shoes were too tight.
Which is your longest finger? Is it the same one for every person in the class?
Draw and write the name of the tallest person and the shortest person in your family.
Draw a line on a paper. Then draw a shorter line under it.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
With a partner, take turns using blocks to measure your feet.

attributes.alt:
Big Chart of Big Ideas for I Can Measure. Chart shows a ruler, a scale, a cup, and a thermometer.
Ruler: A hand holds on to a ruler with a short and long pencil next to it.
Scale: A child puts a heavy rock on one side of a scale. A feather is on the other side of the scale.
Cup: A girl pours a little juice into one cup. The cup next to it has a lot of juice in it.
Thermometer: A thermometer has a very low temperature with a snowman behind it. Next to it, finger points to a high temperature on another thermometer showing it is hot.
Cover for This Shoe Needs a Foot by Caedyn Melach. Cover shows 8 different animal paws, a ruler, and a single shoe with a scared face in the center.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about measuring things, have a hunt for pairs of bigger and smaller objects, and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of math words.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.

Know the purpose of common measuring tools; Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like heavy and light; Use formal or informal measurement tools to observe and describe weight, length, and volume.
Use simple tools to measure and learn about different objects.
Revisit vocabulary words and show children a series of picture cards of different items.
Have children sort the items into “heavy” and “light” categories.
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
Find a long book. Compare it to a short book.
Pretend you are a cat. How  would you walk?
Get five pencils, and put them in order from the shortest to the longest.
Can you draw a measuring tool? What does your measuring tool measure?
Paint a picture of a heavy animal.
What is the first letter in the word
? What is the first letter in the word
Build something heavy out of blocks.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
How did the animals help the shoe find the right foot?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share inferences, predictions, or conclusions about a text.
Understand and use a growing number of math words.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use simple tools to measure and learn about different objects; Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Show interest and appreciation for others’ work.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What did you learn this week about measuring things?
Save children’s writing or drawing to display next week.
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
Can you find a story about a big creature?
Pretend you are now as small as an ant. Show how you would move around the classroom.
Put three blocks in a paper bag. Then put one block in another paper bag. Have a partner decide which bag is heavier.
Draw a picture of something big and something small.
Imagine the heaviest animal in the world. What letter makes the beginning sound of the animal?
Can you use blocks to build a tower that goes from your feet to your knees?
